comment.body: Hello!
@Kasota: Thanks
Hello!
@sthetz: It has already been proven that AIDS is *not* caused by homosexuality.
There's bit.surf
It uses markdown. So you would use `[what is shown](the link address)`. For example `[Thunderwave](http://127.0.0.1:43110/thunderwave.bit)` will produce this result: [Thunderwave](/thunderwave.bit)

Here's a website (on the clearnet) that shows other markdown things: http://commonmark.org/help/. I don't know if all of them work on here though, like the images. But the text formatting ones should, like bold, italics, etc.
@Glightstar: Oh yeah, forgot about that.

@Kaffie: Software can be commercial and free at the same time by using a dual license. Oracle's MySQL is like this. https://www.mysql.com/about/legal/licensing/oem/. Therefore, Oracle has made this paid software free. GPL doesn't restrict the sale of the software. It just requires you to release your code, so you can still have it be paid software. However, you can also charge for the source code. So technically **you are still releasing your code, but only to the people who paid for it.** And they are then free to redistribute, copy, modify, etc. that source code once they bought it. **Distribution happens at the point of sale and this is when you get the source code**. Therefore, because of this, I believe the quoted textbook is wrong because GPL does allow you to sell your software, as long as you release the source code *at the point of distribution*. This is how I understand it, but I may be wrong. But I did research this a little and this is what I have read from a few different sources.

@ Kaffie: also when he said:
> If the use of software requires a fee - this is not free software.
I think he was meaning that whether something is Free Software is *not dependent on whether you have to pay for it or not*. Free software can be paid.

@Kaffie: It explicitly states in the GPL license that you can charge a fee for your software, therefore it *does* allow its use in commercial production. And it's free because people can still copy, modify, distribute (etc.) it. It's literally as simple as that.
**Directly from the GPL 2 license:**
> For example, if you **distribute** copies of such a program, **whether
> gratis or for a fee**, you must give the **recipients** all the rights that
> you have.  You must make sure that *they*, too, ***receive* or can get the
> source code.**  And you must show them these terms so they know their
> rights.
It applies to *recipients* of the product, not to everyone.

@Kaffie: Red Hat distributes the source code only to people who paid for the product I believe. This is how CentOS can build Red Hat's source code and, because it's GPL, distribute it for free. Enterprises are the ones who pay for Red Hat. Regular people mostly just use CentOS. But, Red Hat also comes with more support, faster updates, etc. (basically many of the things Enterprises would want). And correction, apparently it's specifically called Red Hat Enterprise Linux (because Red Hat is for the unsupported and free old versions).

@Kaffie: Sorry, you might have seen that I have edited my comments like a thousand times. I do that a lot because I end up wanting to change something to either make it more understandable, remove stuff I'm not so sure of, make sure it doesn't come off as being rude/mean, make sure I am actually saying accurate information, add stuff I missed, etc.

@Kaffie: Free software doesn't mean there are no restrictions. You're basically saying that nothing is free if they have restrictions. Therefore, according to you, the US isn't free at all. To me, that makes no sense. IMO, there should be some restrictions for certain things (like killing a person, perhaps). This isn't to say that the restrictions given in GPL are restricting the right things, but it is pretty much still free nonetheless. But that doesn't matter because the definition of Free software isn't *necessarily* the same definition of something that is free. As long as you can use, modify, distribute, etc. in any way *even with* restrictions, it's free software - that's how I understand it. However, I will say that I never use GPL unless required by libraries I use. (Also note that BSD 2-clause also has at least *some* restrictions like many other licenses)
@Musickiller: I wonder if there's dd on Windows Subsystem for Linux?

@Musickiller: Actually, *I think* Windows Subsystem for Linux was released in either the last updates, or the one before that, I'm not completely sure - you just need to enable it in the Windows Features. Also, imo the "spying" they are doing is to see whether they need to fix anything. It lets them determine whether computers are being slow and why, what crashes/errors happened, etc. This has already helped them out a lot by helping them detect and fix crashes. I don't really see a problem with them getting *this type* of information. I think people over exaggerate this stuff. Especially since many companies do the same things. Mozilla collects information like this to check for speeds and crashes too. It's a much better way to do it than to just sit there waiting for people to tell you whether your program crashed, which many people don't do. It lets you get more accurate results.

@Jayofthezero: @Musickiller: I believe they worked on allowing access to hard drives, usbs, etc. from WSL. I remember it being mentioned somewhere.

@Musickiller: That's understandable, but why wouldn't you want to share crash reports?

If any of you can read english, I detail ideas for multilanguage support in the future [in this post](/ZeroMedium.bit/?/12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu/zeromedium-details). You can respond with ideas that you have. Right now, it's fine that people post in whatever language they want until I can get this solved.
@Musickiller: What sucks is a lot of ISPs in the US are geographic monopolies.

@Jayofthezero: Where I'm living we only have Cable One or Century Link, and our Century Link is slower than what other people can get in other areas with Century Link. I actually am just waiting for the day Google comes in with their Google Fiber, because hopefully that will create more competition and improve the market, but that won't be forever, because it seems our city is the last to get anything (Sprint's 4G didn't get here until very recently, this year or late last year).

@РоІаr: It's not completely as simple as this, because comments and the view count won't work. You'd have to write that stuff manually from scratch because ZeroNet has a different way to handle that stuff than how the clearnet handles it. However, if the site is just html, css, javascript, markdown, json (basically stuff that's *not* server-side), then it should work.

@Ret0x7c00: If you want to get into Zite development, there are some tutorials on my [ZeroNet Dev Center](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/) zite, and I'm working on a utility that will make it easier to setup the database for a zite, called [ZeroDB Helper](/1EKfFGBWNHLTpPHsfTz3YfSd6nkNM9q4Yf/). I also might start working on more tutorials for the ZeroNet Dev Center soon.
There's Manjaro and Antergos, both based on Arch Linux. Antergos is sometimes called an Arch Linux Installer.
@43110: bit.surf hasn't worked for me in a long time.
@Musickiller: If you don't want to go through setting up your own blog and getting peers, you can use [ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit) :)

1. No it's not. If the title isn't unique, the url will have the date the story was posted appended to it. I made sure to do this so url's won't collide.
2. I believe this is a bug with ZeroNet, not ZeroMedium. However, I will take a look just to make sure.

If you find anymore things which you think are bugs, do tell me - it's better to be safe than sorry. Thanks for using ZeroMedium, btw! :)

@Nofish: Oh, I thought that you had to because it doesn't show up as bold.
